qas.question: Which part of Eritrea's health care goals have they been most successful in?
What was the Eritrean life expectancy at birth in 1960?
What was the Eritrean life expectancy st birth in 2008?
Which practice was banned by the Eritrean government with claimes it is painful and has life-threatening health problems for women?
How much did the National Malaria Protection Unit reduce malarial mortality by from 1998 - 2006?
In what year was female genital mutilation banned in Eretria?
How many kids had been vaccinated against measles in 2008?
What was the life expectancy in 2006 in Eretria?
In what year was the Millenium Development Goal targets put in place?
When was the World Health Organisation established?

context: Eritrea has achieved significant improvements in health care and is one of the few countries to be on target to meet its Millennium Development Goal (MDG) targets in health, in particular <a0_0>child health<a0_0/>. Life expectancy at birth has increased from <a1_0>39.1<a1_0/> in <b9_0>1960<b9_0/> to <a2_0><b7_0>59.5<b7_0/><a2_0/> years in 2008, maternal and child mortality rates have dropped dramatically and the health infrastructure has been expanded. Due to Eritrea's relative isolation, information and resources are extremely limited and according to the World Health Organisation (WHO) found in 2008 average life expectancy to be slightly less than 63 years. Immunisation and child nutrition has been tackled by working closely with schools in a multi-sectoral approach; the number of children vaccinated against measles almost doubled in seven years, from 40.7% to <b6_0>78.5%<b6_0/> and the underweight prevalence among children decreased by 12% in 1995–<b8_0>2002<b8_0/> (severe underweight prevalence by 28%). The National Malaria Protection Unit of the Ministry of Health has registered tremendous improvements in reducing malarial mortality by as much as <a4_0>85%<a4_0/> and the number of cases by 92% between 1998 and <b5_0>2006<b5_0/>. The Eritrean government has banned <a3_0>female genital mutilation<a3_0/> (FGM), saying the practice was painful and put women at risk of life-threatening health problems.
